thread.title: Broadway shopping centre in $55m facelift

title: Broadway shopping centre in $55m facelift
text:
The Broadway shopping centre is in for a $55 million upgrade.
Mirvac is set to undertake a $55 million upgrade of its Broadway shopping centre that will result in it expanding into one of the larger inner-city malls in the southern precinct of the Sydney CBD.
Under the plan, co-owners Mirvac and the private Perron Group will add new fashion and food areas to cater for the growing number of residents in the area â€“ from students at the University of Technology Sydney to the Central Park apartments.
The new Lend Lease development around Haymarket, including the $3.4 billion International Convention Centre and new Sofitel project, will also increase demand for a greater variety of retailers at the southern end of the City.
The new sites at Broadway will include a 3400-square-metre expansion of level two, which will deliver about 31 in-demand retailers and a new mini-major. The redevelopment will increase the centre's food and fashion retail offer in response to the growing customer demand for aspirational fashion and new casual food and dining formats.
Advertisement Broadway Shopping Centre took out the honours this year when it became the first mall in Australia to crack the $12,000 sales per-square-metre mark. Broadway increased its moving average turnover per square metre by 6.4 per cent to a record $12,248 a square metre a year.
The redevelopment comes as Australia benefits from a continued influx of foreign entrants, with 40 new-store openings last year by new or expanding retailers and a further 12 openings in the first half of 2015.
CBRE head of research Australia Stephen McNabb said this was helping to drive CBD rental growth, with Sydney CBD rents having increased 20 per cent in the past 12 months and rental growth having also been recorded in the shopping centre sector.
He said the conditions were improving with the leasing spreads moving back into positive territory, and there remained a low risk of oversupply for malls.
In the core of the city in Pitt Street Mall, activity is also hotting up with the Swedish giant H&M set to take over the keys at its site at the Stockland-Investa Glasshouse, in readiness for an internal fit-out. It is likely to open about September.
